comments.commentBody: I'd have to be Old Spice.
Many years ago, Daddy liked to ask my sisters and me, "Juno what the capital of ALASKA is?" (He's 83 now, and still corny.)  So I had the punchline, if not the right joke.  Enjoyed the puzzle!

NachoHomey--Thanks for your hopes and wishes.

One more round of chemo--and then--with luck--nothing to left to focus on beyond the rest of our lived, the November elections and conservative hypocrisy.

as I write from the Cradle of Liberty i think it's time for the tea leaflets party to reinvent themselves, like becoming the ford, baseball or cracker jack party, since tea is not even indigenous to this wonderful country. How patriotic is that? And Whew think of all your criticisms of our American president. Come to the game guys and get a clue.

@ John Drew:  Finally, you make an argument, shabby though it is on so many counts.  Didn't you get a social science degree? Paying so little heed to the facts at hand?  OK, so you looked up the GWU student demographics and got the male/white percentages right.  Then you leapt to an assumption that only adds weight to your argument but is not supported by any fact. Namely, that the University somehow mucked around with the representation in selecting a commencement speaker. They should've, according to you stats, picked a white male.  How do you know what the selection process was ---was it an open call, was it a sifting of grades to nnarrow the applicant field? Were they a diverse group or was it skewered to begin with?  You don't know but that hardly stops you from making your point (regardless of facts or forum) that young white males are a forgotten, trampled upon group.  If you went to GWU, they'd fail you for lack of supporting evidence on your tenious thesis.

Chris: :"Are you saying that 3 million times a year an American has to use a firearm to defend himself against another American?"

No "has to", but does. There are over a dozen studies on this topic and the methodologies differ. The consensus range is 800,000 to 3.5 million successful defensive gun uses (DGU's) per year. Those are all crime that WOULD have happened, but did not.
Bill Clinton admitted today that Larry Summers and Richard Rubin gave him bad advice on derivatives.  Seems to me we are about to come full circle.

Let's see...these highly educated Teabaggers think that Obama wasn't born here. That would just show that despite an education those hard right Repugnatcans won't let facts get in the way of opinions.
Yeah right John. I thought you were terrified and frightened just yesterday. You change like a weather vain.

Zoe you deserve it. I think you're an awesome representation of what Elliott and GWU really stands for, and I can't wait to hear your speech. I'm sure it'll be amazing. Anyways, if we made it thru PSC 101 (quite well I must add since people here are questioning academic merit, dont listen to them!) haha and I think that was an accomplishment all on its own. Best of luck!

Auggie, the fact is that Obama was elected by the majority of the electorate. You seem to have trouble differentiating between fact and opinion. I notice also that in your other post you did attach "marxist socialist agenda" to Obama's name. You seem to think that "Marxist socialist agenda"  is part of his name. The fact is that Bush came into office with a nice budget surplus and projections of that to continue. When W. left office there were huge deficits, which remain. They were the fault of W. and his totally compliant congress, which he enjoyed for 6 years.

More ado about nothing from the left. Clinton today admitted that Summers and Rubin gave him bad advice on derivatives. Throw in Sandy Weill creating CitiGROUP in direct contravention of Glass Stegall and viola, we're where we are today. With a few tweaks from Fannie and Freddie, Frank and Franklin, Chris and Mario and Mel and Maxine along the way. Summers is still there!! The list of Goldman acolytes in this administration is well over a dozen, in high places.

If you're gonna clean out the chicken coop, you run the fox out first.

To Paul at post number 43:

I appreciate your post--though truth be told--my use of "Kenyan" was intentional.

It was intended to be a wry--but perhaps too obscure-- reference to the opposition's "birther" wing--and their ongoing claptrap to the effect that the President is not a U.S. citizen.

I know of John. M Keynes.

And remain a fan of--and advocate for--his take on economics.
To @ Augustine:  You have a Phd in political science?! Ask for your money back!

Ph.d. Mr. Drew. I know you will say that i am just a little old limo driver and you have your degree. Well John can you expalin why I have been booked solid since January 2009, and have had one slow quarter in the past three years? I realize that my client base of senior level executives, many of whom run Fortune 100 companies here in Minneapolis, are only considered customers to you. Those are your words John.

Explain and enlighten us as to why they, my clients, are all seeing strong growth, increased orders and quarterly earnings going up. I just had my strongerst first quarter ever. Employment in my home is 100 percent and we are looking forward to a very strong year. Things here in this high tax state are looking very good John. By the way we have been DEMOCRATICALLY controlled for 60 years. Explain that John.

We await your disertation of one paragraph.

So let's arm all the children going to school each day right Mr. Drew Ph.d.?

For a man as erudite as you, you don't know much.

To paulie: spot on.

We need to tax investment gains at the same rates as labor. If you consider the reduced tax rates for investment income and that the wealthy pay no income or social security taxes on their large tax-free accounts and on unrealized capital gains, you see how labor income can end up being taxed at rates 5-10 times investment income and gains. This economic distortion and our ongoing wealth concentration creates a situation in which too much investment money chases too few worthy investments ... bubble...burst.....recession, in which the poor and middle class end up suffering the most. An alternative would be to do away with taxes on investment income and gains and instead tax wealth directly.

[A VAT, especially one that replaces all or part of income taxes, will do just the opposite. The poor middle class spend almost all their income, so they get almost all their income taxed. The very wealthy spend a small part of their income and so they get only that small part of their income taxed.]

The cry will go up that investment and a wealthy investing class is needed to create jobs. (Supply side trickle down.) Look at recent history:

In 1993 under President Clinton, taxes on upper incomes were increased. Many Republican congressmen predicted this would lead to a recession, "kill jobs," and so increase the federal deficit. There are many influences on the economy. That said, this tax increase on the rich was followed by: the US's longest peacetime economic expansion; the creation of 23 million new jobs in eight years'; an increase in the median household income by $6000 over eight years; high tax revenue, elimination of the federal deficit, the first surpluses in 40 years; and low inflation.

In 1997 President Clinton signed a law giving investment gains favored tax treatment over income from work. Perhaps this economic distortion contributed to the "irrational exuberance" dot-com stock market bubble. That bubble burst 4 years later, which in turn contributed to the 2001-03 recession. Two-thirds of President Bush's 2001 and 2003 tax cuts went to the top 5% incomes earners. They gave further favored tax treatment to the investing class. He said the cuts would stimulate the economy, create jobs, and so increase tax revenue. His tax cuts for the rich were followed by: a choppy economy (average GDP growth a low 2.5%); only 3 million new jobs (1/8th of Clinton & the lowest rate among last 11 presidents); widening economic disparity between poor and rich; a decrease in the median household income by $1000 over eight years; a large drop in tax revenue with doubling of the national debt; and the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression of the 1930's.

For more see: http://fairsharetaxes.org

The San Francisco Chronicle is quoting a pool report stating that the President's remarks were interrupted by protesters urging the repeal of "Don't Ask, Don't Tell." I certainly think it's relevant to the story. http://www.sfgate.com...

Anatomy of a Clean-up Man …Take #1.

First and foremost, it’s a messy job, but someone had to do it. Wiktionay defines clean-up as: “…make an area or thing clean; pick up a mess, tidy…or clean house.”

In Washington, the recent bitterly-partisan, GOP-obstructionist, and mean-spirited debates over healthcare reform, finance reform, panic-poll results, and the “of a sudden” flawed-invocation of the 1773 Boston Tea Party needs closure.

The attire of choice: basic blue-jean overalls. Custom-tailored suits and wing-tip-shoes might work on Wall Street, but they’ll encounter pent-up hostility on Main Street.

That’s because the clean-up man’ work-environment is often fraught with great perils… one man’ known carcinogens… asbestos or coal dust, is yet another man’s toxic-asset derivatives.

Reaching back down through the annals of American history, a few presidential clean-up men have been lauded for their efforts with their namesakes affixed to federal buildings, parks, and hospitals.

In walks President Obama into history with Healthcare and Finance Reform… not unlike two of his predecessors, deemed worthy enough to clean-up after the Republicans.

Challenging problems against a backdrop or political climate of social unrest, yet on-going wars… not unlike the Civil War and Vietnam War eras, vexing economic-disparity and the usual threats of secessionist violence has thus far not stopped the young and fiscal-agile 44th American president.

Blowing inland along the banks of the Potomac River amid the frigid political-winds, equally chaotic and controversial times greeted President Abraham Lincoln before and after the 1862 banishment of slavery, as well President Lyndon Baines Johnson' 1964 Civil Rights Bill.

And the change we've sought and yet beg need not stop merely at the doorstep of President Barack Obama' White House. No, for centuries henceforth...when we've all but exited this earthly stage, hope which springs eternal… hope-as well change, will keep "blowin’ in the wind."

Our response… “Answers,” to these great challenges… “Questions,” facing America and the world-at-large will determine the fate of not just our generation, but of those generations who'll invariably follow.

Increasingly the business commentators, even the ones supporting GS are beginning to admit that the Market is really a gambling casino. In a gambling casino everyone knows just what their chances are; in the Market they were long under the impression that the investment banks had a fiduciary obligation to their investors. The truth is that the investment banks have never had a fiduciary obligation to their investors, no matter what their advertisements said.

If GS wins this it will only be after the general public learns that GS, and all the other investment banks, have only operated in their own interests. The result of that should be a new awareness on the part of the public that their money is not safely invested with GS and any other company that acts the way that they did. Eventually, Unions and companies will be forced by their investors, employees, and members,to invest their pension funds in simpler, easier to understand investments. The eventual cost to GS will be enormous.

Also, there will be lawsuits against GS and other investment banks using the same tactics by Germany, the UK and other countries. The results of such suits in Europe may not be favorable to GS and the other investment banks because the rules there may be more restrictive, or they may just be looking to get back and the monstrous banks.

No matter the result, the days of investment banks that act for themselves alone may be numbered. Well, we can hope can't we?

The point here is less about the ability of the SEC to win or not. Any Jury simply isnt going to understand what a synthetic CDO is, let alone who was right or wrong from a pure legal standpoint.

The overriding argument is Goldman Sachs "manufactured" a product for which they got paid a healthy fee, that created a massive multimillion dollar win for "one sophisticated investor". On the otherside was supposedly "another sophisticated investor".

Except there wasn't. That person blew up, leaving you, me and our equivalents in Germany, England and elsewhere to pay a billionaire via wall street, his winnings.

It that is whats massively wrong, and what Goldman Sachs doesnt seem to 'get'.
Common sense says they are all guilty as sin.  So, get a jury of everyday, middle class people and spell it out.  Voila, jail!
And not only were billions of dollars handed out as bonuses in January but now in April too...

I have one question for all of the posters here who are convinced that President Obama was bought by GS so that he would bail them out. Do you recall that it was Bush and Secretary Paulson that engineered the financial bail out in the fall of 2008 as well as a bail out for GM shortly after?

In fact, the Great Recession is deemed by experts to have begun in December 2007 which was under Bush's watch. And the initial "700 billion dollar bail out" was pledged prior to the 2008 presidential election.
When dealing with Goldman, treat it like a poker game: if you don't see a patsy around the table, YOU'RE THE PATSY.
